title: Which country will win the 2020 Olympic gold medal in men’s synchronized 3-meter springboard diving?
possible_answers: No gold medal will be awarded for this event
preds: Adjusted to normalized odds from www.oddsshark.com  The crowd may have fallen into an extremizing feedback on this one.

One bad dive in the Men's 10-Meter synchronized platform caused the Chinese men's diving team to lose the gold metal by a very close margin: https://olympics.com/tokyo-2020/olympic-games/en/results/diving/results-men-s-synchronised-10m-platform-fnl-000100-.htm They dominated the remainder of the other dives.  Team GB had a great performance! The pressure will be high on the Chinese 3M synchronized team.  As I previous highlighted, this combination of athletes has not competed in a global diving event together [https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1309054].  Experience and team chemistry should not be underestimated.   I am inclined to lean against the trend (i.e. lowering China's likelihood of winning) as I believe Chinese athletes will respond well to pressure.  China is still favored.
China at 88% seems too high.  Odds seem to imply that it should be closer to 60%.  GB at 15% or so.  Rest farther behind.

Increasing chances for China to win [https://apnews.com/article/china-tokyo-diving-olympic-games-2020-tokyo-olympics-fa6cbe630d4cda26a12a08b503fdb101]; however, it is worth noting that the composition of China's synchronized 3-meter springboard diving team has changed from the 2019 World Championships.   In 2019, for this event China had Yuan and Siyi.  For the Olympics, it appear it will be Wang Zongyuan and Xie Siyi [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics#Diving].  As Siyi is a very experienced diver with a proven track record, I will focus my next comments on Zongyuan.  He appears to be 19-years old and has not competed at the 3M in a global competition.  He won the 1M in the 2019 World Championships [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wang_Zongyuan].  And I have no evidence of competitive records in a synchronized event. At the same time, team Great Britain is returning the same team from the 2019 World Championships with Goodfellow and Laugher [https://www.britishswimming.org/news/diving-news/british-diving-name-team-tokyo-world-cup/].  Experience and team chemistry should not be underestimated for this event.

More than a 1% chance that the event doesn't happen, but not 2%. China historically; thanks to @the_trumpet_vine  for the links. The shifts between Mexico, Germany, Russia in recent international competitions indicates that silver can be noisy.

Aggregating other comments (especially the one from @clewey who's convincing / quasi-exhaustive + other comments that suggest that US has a shot aswell), I reached this point where China are the most likely, Great Britain the second ones and US seems to have a chance.

China has dominated diving at the world championships and Olympics.  If we use the last five olympics, China has won 3 gold metals, with Great Britain winning one, as well as Greece.  At the same time Russia has won 3 silver metals (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Olympic_medalists_in_diving#Synchronized_3_metre_springboard).  Let's assume base rates of 60% for China, with 20% for Great Britain and 20% for Greece. At the most recent world championships in 2019, China won 12 of the 13 potential medals (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diving_at_the_2019_World_Aquatics_Championships).    Finally, if you consider the most recent FINA diving results (note: China did not participate), Great Britain won (https://www.the-sports.org/diving-fina-diving-world-cup-results-2021-men-epm105435.html).  At the same time Greece was not involved (and placed very low at the most recent European Championships).  Finally Germany and Russia performed well.  Given Russia's history of Silver metals, they should not be counted out. Note: The forecast includes a 1% probability that no gold metals will be award for this event.  I would honestly want to push this to 0.1%.  This event is at the end of the first week of the Olympics.  From a timing perspective, we should know by then if there is covid-19 in the Olympic village.  This may cause events to be postponed or cancelled.  Unfortunately, this is a non-zero probability.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diving_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_synchronized_3_metre_springboard https://www.charlotteobserver.com/sports/article252502758.html China has dominated last 3 olympics, their sports venues have grown and globalization have made them more competitive. US and GB might have a shot
